awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Navigation in Naturalistic and Changing Environments: Perception, Learning and Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early-Career Development (CAREER) award supports an integrated research and education project aimed at determining how insects navigate in complex environments. The ultimate goal of this project is to determine how animals navigate in dynamic environments to advance our understanding of the perceptual, learning, and memory mechanisms underlying navigation. The outcomes of this research provide an understanding of dynamic control systems, reveal how the nervous system has evolved to handle unpredictability, and drive the development of novel navigational algorithms and biological sensors.  This project is designed to provide learning and research opportunities to expand interdisciplinary education for underrepresented groups in the STEM majors. The investigator integrates this research into curriculum at multiple levels: (i) an introductory module that engages first-year biology students to use models and simulations to understand how animals move through the world; (ii) the development of a summer research program that recruits undergraduate students; (iii) the establishment of collaboration with high-school biology teachers to help establish the interdisciplinary approach to biology education before students enter university.

Insect navigation studies have a long history, but the mechanisms of control in changing naturalistic environments remain relatively unexamined. An integrative approach is used to elucidate how perception of the environment is computed and stored in the nervous system and acted upon by an organism. There are three major aims in the proposed research:  (i) identify the local and global visual features that ants extract from naturalistic panoramic scenes; (ii) determine how the viewing behavior of ants comes to be directed towards the local and global cues used for route guidance; (iii) define the role of memory in stabilizing routes in the face of change. The proposed research brings the unpredictable nature of the field into the lab by employing virtual naturalistic environments in which complexity and instability can be introduced in a systematic fashion.  For example, the investigator can add, remove, or displace the visual features within a scene in a closed-loop fashion simulating natural occurring changes in lighting conditions, wind displacement, and terrain geometry. This research is of general interest to visual and behavioral neuroscientists and to computer scientists working with autonomous robots.  Visually dependent tasks that are broadly similar across a wide variety of animals with well-developed visual systems tend to have areas of convergence in their generating algorithms (e.g. path integration, visually guided navigation), although the specific neural implementation may differ between species. Insect navigational behavior provides an ideal platform to develop precise control models to describe and simulate cellular events, neural circuits, and complex behavior.

por.por_cntn:
This Faculty Early-Career Development (CAREER) award supported an integrated research and education project aiming to determine how insects navigate in complex environments. Visually dependent tasks that are broadly similar across a variety of animals with well-developed visual systems tend to have areas of convergence in their generating algorithms (e.g., path integration, visually guided navigation), though the specific neural implementation may differ between species. In this project, we developed new computational models to better understand how ants forage in natural environments. Our work has provided insight into the mechanisms involved in the prioritization and perception of visual information. Our results suggest that ants need only processes relevant cues intermittently and do not continually process visual information. Additionally, we investigated how the learning and storage of spatial information could be optimized in simple networks and nervous systems. This work has provided us with a platform to describe and simulate cellular events, neural circuits, and complex behaviors. In this project, we demonstrated that ants foraging using a naturalistic scene will refine and learn their routes by progressively reducing and directing their saccade-like turns towards not only prominent features within the panorama but integrated elements of the scene. This resulted in ants being able to maintain their learned, stable foraging routes even when we simulated naturalistic changes to their visual environment (e.g., dense fog obscuring features and objects, a prominent tree falling over within the panoramic scene).

The CAREER education plan focused on increasing interdisciplinary biology education in the university setting and exposing students to this type of education during their K-12 years. Several interdisciplinary biology modules were developed and implemented in the university classroom. These included case studies based on primary research and research from the lab using computational approaches to study visual processing in insects. We developed "Ant Vision" an augmented reality application that was used in the classroom to provide students with an opportunity to explore navigational processes and has allowed us to test our algorithms and predictions from our research on a large scale while engaging students. Students were trained in 3D printing, Raspberry PI, Python, and MATLAB. Finally, several high school students participated in hands-on research integrating biology, engineering, and computer science. This work resulted in papers and several presentations and has provided the foundation to expand our interdisciplinary biology curriculum.

Importantly, this project provided learning and research opportunities to expand interdisciplinary education for underrepresented groups at Fresno State. Fresno State is a primarily undergraduate institution and is both a Hispanic Serving and an Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander Serving Institution. This award supported efforts to reduce disparity and increase equity in STEM. More than 30 students from diverse backgrounds contributed to the research goals or took part in the educational initiatives for this award. This involvement positively impacted their careers, with many going on to Ph.D. programs and jobs in STEM. We also established partnerships with the National Parks Services and the Fresno Chaffee Zoo and integrated research, education, and public outreach, furthering the broader impacts of this award.
